mitted for trial; if you do not get out of the way, you will be taken too"—he said, "Well, I am much obliged to you, and am very sorry for poor Oliver," (Blackford is called Oliver,) "because I can prove him innocent"—he said he knew if he was not taken for that, he would be for something else—I could not see a policeman handy, and took him to have a pot of beer—I got talking to him, and said, "Why do not you go to Blackford, and see if

you can settle it with him"—he said, "If you can tell how, I will"—I said, "Go and tell him you will come up on the day of trial," or something of that—he said he did not settle it in that way—I said, "If you wrote the orders, you are not obliged to tell them so"—he said, "I did not write the orders, but I fetched the files myself"—I went out, fetched a policeman, and gave him into custody—when he was taken he said, "You have done a b----fine thing for me"—one of Mr. Winter's clerks charged him, and he was locked up.

THOMAS TAYLOR. In March last I was in the service of Mr. Wild, a whitesmith, in Mint-street. On 30th March I was standing at the door, and saw the two prisoners—Malme told my master he had got three dozen of 16-inch files for sale—he asked 8s. a dozen for them—Harrington was stand
ing at the post opposite—about a fortnight afterwards I was with my master in Horsemonger-lane, and saw Malme—I pointed him out to Mr. Wild, who went and had some conversation with him—he ultimately gave him into cus
tody—I believe there was some one with him, but I cannot say—I did not see Harrington.
Malme. This man was not in the shop; I was at the door.

WILLIAM BLACKFORD. I live in College-street, Tooley-street. On 3rd May I met Harrington, who I did not know before, at the Marquis of Granby public-house, in the Borough—I was at that time admitted to bail by the Magistrate, having been spoken to by Gardiner as being the person that came for the files—I was reading a bill outside the public-house, and Harrington came up to me, and asked how I thought I should get on—I asked, "For what?"—he said, "For the job at Mr. Winter's"—I said, "I hardly know"—he said, "I am very sorry, as I know you are innocent of it; it was me and Malme that got the goods on the Thursday and Friday; I went to Malme, and told him if he would write out another order, we could get some more on the Saturday; and Malme went in and presented the bill, and I was on the opposite side of the way"—he was in my company about three hours and a half—on these facts being stated, the Magistrate discharged me.

COURT. Q. Was it not you that presented the order to Gardiner? A. No; he supposed it was me—I had nothing to do with it—I was at home, and had witnesses to prove it—I go by the name of Oliver—Malme was not with Harrington when this conversation occured.
Harrington. I was not with him above ten minutes, and nothing of the sort passed between us; I know nothing about it.

RICHARD GASH (policeman, M 35.) I took Malme into custody—I told him he was charged with being concerned with others in obtaining files from Messrs. Winter and Rich, of Bankside, by means of a forged order—Wild was with me—Malme turned round and said to him, "What a b----fine mess you have got me into; I did not think you would let me into it like this"—I took him to the station—on the way he said several times, "I am sure when they see me they will know me," or "swear to me"—he did not say why he thought so.

STEPHEN GARDINER
re-examined. My impression is that Malme and Blackford are so much alike that I may probably be mistaken in Blackford—the coat he wore was very much like the one Malme has on—before the Magistrate I spoke of Blackford without any hesitation—I did not notice any one outside when the order was presented.
Malme's Defence. I met a man, who asked me to sell the files for him, and I went to young Wild; Harrington was not with me.

p.hi: There being no proof that the order was not written by Mr. Turner, the prisoners were

div1.p:
1425.
EDWARD HARRINGTON was again indicted
for feloniously uttering a forged order for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
George Winter and another.

STEPHEN GARDINER. This order for the delivery of axle-trees, purporting to be dated 3rd Dec., 1846, I received from the prisoner—I belived them is be for Mr. King, a customer, and delivered him a set of mail-pattern axle-trees, worth about 4l.
HENRY JOHN FOSTER. In Dec., 1846, I was in the service of Mr. George Winter and Mr. Rich—the prisoner came with this order—I was present when Gardiner received it.

Prisoner. I never saw the man in my life. Witness. I am suere he is the same man; his height and everything is the same—he had a different dress on—he was backwards and forwards in his cart for nearly a month—I recognized him directly before the Magistrate—there were a dozen others there.

ABRAHAM KING. I live in York-street, Lambeth, and am a smith, and a customer of Winter and Rich—I did not send this order, and know nothing about it—I never saw the prisoner till he was at the Police-court—I always write my own orders—this is very nearly like my writing—I do not know whose it is—no one in my employ writes orders for me—Malme was never in my employ—several young men have left my service since Dec., 1846—none of them were like the prisoner so as to be mistaken for him—(Order read. Dec. 3, 1846. Sir,—Please let bearer have a set of mail-patters axle-trees A. King.)

GUILTY.—Aged 20.—
Confined Eighteen Months.
(There were two other indictments against both the prisoners.)

1426.
JOSEPH ANTHONY
, feloniously killing and slaying
James Wilks.

p.hi: The indictment alleged the cause of death to be a rupture of the duodenan and it appearing that it was produced by a shock to the nervous system, the

div1.p:
1427.
JOHN HARDING
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Edward Jobling in the side, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

EDWARD JOBLING. I am apprenticed to the prisoner, who is a shoemaker. On Monday morning, 8th May, I found two or three pieces of something that looked like pewter in the coal scuttle, and showed them to the other apprentice—my mistress happened to see it, and told my master—he tole me to go and shake a piece of carpet—I did so, and when I came in he had a cane in his hand, and caught hold of my collar, and hit me with it, and said, "Have I been melting pots?"—I said, "No, sir, I did not say such a thing as that; I said that it looked like pewter"—he only struck me once them—he told me to go and clean the outside windows—I did so, and then asked him what I should do—he told me to sit down, and make a ten-cord thread—I sat down to make it, and he then told me to wipe up some water—I went to get something to do it with, and he said I had got the hemp entangled on purpose, and began to cane me—I cannot say how many times he struck me; he kept on a good time—I struggled, and kicked him twice—he said he

would learn me to kick—I then sat down, and went on again making the thread—I felt the blood running down, and when the other apprentice, Hine, went out with a pair to shoes to the Blackfriars-road, I told my haster of it—I had not mentioned it to Hine—I said, "You have cut my side open, Sir; "and he said, "It served you right, and I wish it was worse"—I did not show him the blood—the blood had been running half an hour when Hine went out—my master was in the room while I was working, before Hine went out; it was in the shop—my master was there all the time—there was a knife lying on the cutting-board, about a yard from my master—he stood up when he caned me—I did not see the knife while he was caning me; I saw it in his hand about ten minutes before—I did not see it again that day that I recollect—I do not know the moment when I was cut.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Was he in the room all the time from the time he thrashed you till you said you were cut? A. Yes; he went up stairs afterwards—he did mot go up before I told him he had cut me—I was working close to him—there are three stools;his was in the middle—I only showed the pewter to Hine; I did not say my master had been stealing a pint pot—my master did not say I had said so—I did not call him a liar; I said it was a story; that I had said no such thing—I have been taken before a Magistrate once for bad behaviour—he threatened to send me to the House of Correction for two months—my master said he would give me another trial—I did not stand in the same place all the time he was caning me; I was trying to kick him the whole time—I only kicked him twice—I threatened to kick him, and I did—he said if he caught me doing anything he would make the blood pour down my back; that was on the Monday after he beat me a great deal of good—I felt the blood immediately he had caned me; I felt it with my hand, looked at it about five minutes after—when he went up stairs, I undid my clothes, and saw the blood—I did not tell Hine; he was working there half an hour after I had the wound—I am saucy to my master when he says anything that I do not like; then perhaps I begin to be saucy—I did not tell the policeman (M 165) I had fallen, and I must have got it so—I told two or three at the workhouse how it was done—I did mot tell them I had fallen against the knife—it did not give me much pain;I could not walk as I used to—I sat on a stool opposite Hine—the counter is at my back—I did not say to a boy named Oaker (looking at him) two or three days before this, that if my master beat me again I would stab myself, and say it was him that did it—I said nothing to that effect.

GEORGE ODLING. I am a surgeon, in High-street, Borough. About two o'clock, on 8th May, I examined the boy—I found a wound about an inch and a half above the hip joint—I did not probe it—it had the appearance of a stab—it went through the lining of the trowsers and shirt—I should say this knife (produced) is very likely to produce such a wound—it must have been dine with considerable force to penetrate the lining and shirt—such a wound might be produced from various causes—it is quite possible if the knife had been lying on the bench, and the boy had stumbled against it, it would have produced it—it is not of any importance—it was a clean cut.

ENOCH HINE. I am apprenticed to the prisoner. I was present on 8th May, between ten and eleven o'clock, when he was caning Jobling—I did not see any knife in his hand—I did not see where the knife was at the time, but I found it afterwards, about a quarter past twelve, on my master's seat, its usual place—I saw Jobling kick him twice, and master said, "I Will
teach you to kick me"—I stayed in the shop about twenty minutes after the caning was over—Jobling did not tell me before I went out that he had been wounded.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been in the service? A. Nearly three years—he has been a very good master to me—he never hit me, except for stopping on my errands—he was about a yard or a yard and a half from his seat when he was caning Jobling—I am sure he had not a knife is his hand.
MR. BALDWIN. Q. Could you see both his hands when he was caning the boy? A. Yes—he shoved him away from him, and hit him with the cane.

JOHN CHANNER (policeman, M 24.) I took the prisoner in custody on 8th May, about a quarter to eleven o'clock—I received the boy from a gen
tleman in the Borough, who told me he had been stabbed by his master—the prisoner said he knew nothing of it—he presented me with his cane, which he said was the one he used for correcting him—this is the shirt the boy had on—(produced)—it is stained with blood, and the trowser also—they are cut through—I also produce the knife.
Cross-examined. Q. I belive he said, "I have no knowledge of anything of the kind; I have beaten him this morning?" A. Yes.

1428.
MARY WOOD
, stealing 2 shawls, 33 yards of muslin, and 1 scarf, value 1l., the goods of
James Day Quy, her master.

SOPHIA QUY. I am wife of James Day Quy, a draper, of the Commercial-road—the prisoner was in our service four months—she left on Monday week. I missed two shawls, thirty-three yards of muslin, and a scarf—I had seen the prisoner with one of the shawls on, but did not know it then—my husband afterwards asked her if she had seen it—she said no—he charged her with stealing it—she denied it, and said she bought it in the City—I asked where—she would not tell me—I sent for a constable—Sergeant May came, examined her box, in her presence and mine, and found these two remnants of muslin—(produced)—they are mine—she produced this shawl and scarf out of her box—they are my husband's—she knelt down and said she was very sorry she had taken them, but she had not taken the shawl and piece of muslin—she was not given in charge, but dismissed—she left next morning—the washerwoman's daughter brought me eight yards of muslin, which she had given her for a dress—I showed it to the prisoner, and asked her how she came by it—she said the apprentice, Jessop, gave it her—it is my husband's.
ARTHUR ELSEY JESSOP. I did not give the prisoner this muslin.
JAMES NEALE (policeman.) The prisoner was given into my charge with this shawl on—she said her mistress gave it her.

GUILTY. Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

1429.
THOMAS SMITH
, stealing 2 coats, 2 pairs of trowsers, and other articles, value 24s., the goods of
John Smith.

MARY ANN SMITH. I am the wife of John Smith, who is in the county gaol, Newington. On Wednesday morning, 3rd May, I was coming up the steps of London Bridge, and saw the prisoner at the top of the steps with my hus
band's coat, waistcoat, trowsers, shirt front, scarf, and hat on—he is no relation—I had never seen him before—I asked him if he came from Horsemonger-lane

gaol—he said no—I said he could have got those clothes nowhere else, for they were my husband's—he said, "They were given to me, you had better not go to the gaol, as they country will be obliged to find your husband a much better suit than these, and you will be the loser rather than the gainer by going"—I went over the bridge with him—he said he should not go with me unless I paid him four shillings for his day's work, he was going down Kent-street, and if I liked to follow him I might—I gave him in charge—I went with him to Horsemonger-lane and he was ordered to change his clothes—these clothes (produced) are my husband's—an inside cost and a pair of boots are still missing.
Prisoner. Q. I went a good way with you before you gave me in charge? A. Yes; three parts of the way, and then you said you would not go further without for shillings.

DANIEL HENRY WEST. I am turnkey at Horsemonger-lane. When pri
soners come in, their clothes are given to me; when they go out, I give them back—when the prisoner was going away, he was given into my hands to give him his clothes—I took two prisoners into the clothes-room, turned round and saw this prisoner had a bundle in his arms while I was serving the other—he said, "These are mine"—I put my hand in the hat and took out a name "John Smith," on a piece of paper—I asked the prisoner's name, he said, "John Smith"—(his name is Thomas Smith)—I said, "Are they your clothes?"—he said, "Yes"—we went to the bath-room—the prisoner put on the boots and two coats belonging to John Smith, who is still in the gaol—he left the prison—Mrs. Smith and the policeman afterwards brought him back, and told me in his presence that the clothes were her husband's—he did not deny it—he said I had given them to him—(he had packed the bundle and said they were his)—I made him change them.

Prisoner. Q. Did not the policeman tell you unless you said I took them it would not be conviction? A. No; I never made such a mistake before, and should not now, only you gave me a false name—the ticket that was on the clothes is destroyed—that was not because Thomas Smith was robbed—the Governor did not reprimand me—if any person had come and said his name was John Smith, I should have given him the bundle—it is almost impossible for a person to leave in a counterfeit name—you did not receive a note say
ing that some clothing was sent by your friends—it is usual to destroy's prisoner's clothes if they are in a foul state.

THOMAS FREDERICK LITTLEFIELD. I was on duty in the Borough, and saw Mrs. Smith and the prisoner walking together—the prisoner was given into my charge—I said, "How did you become possessed of the clothes?"—he said they were given to him—I took him to Horsemonger-lane and received this bundle.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you tell West that unless he said I took the clothes it would not be a conviction? A. No.
Prisoner's Defence. I believe the clothes were deposited my friends, mine being destroyed being in a bad state; I received a note from my friends saying they had left clothes for me.

GUILTY. Aged 32.—
Confined One Month.

1430.
FANNY WARREN
, stealing 1 tobacco-box, value 3d., the goods of
William Leveritt, from his person.

WILLIAM LEVERITT. I live at Richmond. I met the prisoner—(I had seen her on a previous night)—she wanted me to go home with her—I de
clined
and sat down on the road and fell asleep—I had a tobacco-box in my pocket with a sovereign in it—this is it (produced)—when I awoke it was gone, and the prisoner also—I was not drunk.
WILLIAM SELBY EDMED (policeman, V 32.) On the 18th, between six and seven o'clock in the morning, I found the tobacco-box in the prisoner's room—the sovereign was not in it.
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me his basket to carry; the box was in it; my little girl opened it.

WILLIAM LEVERITT
re-examined. I gave it to her to carry and forgot to ask her for it when I stopped—I am sure the box was not in it—when found everything was turned out of it.

1431.
WILLIAM WATKINS
, unlawfully assaulting
Elizabeth Shepherd. with intent, &c.

1432.
JOHN GODDING,
SUSAN CAIN , and
CHARLES NICHOL SON
unlawfully receiving 12 files, value 2l., which had been obtained by false pretences.

1433.
FANNY SEARLE
, stealing 1 shift, 1 apron, and 2 books, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Eliza Allum; and 1 blanket, and 1 table-cloth, and other articles, value 18s. 6d.; the goods of
John Slame, her master; to which, she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Four Months.

1434.
CHRISTOPHER CROFTS
, stealing 1 cigar-case, 1 pipe, 1 razor and other articles, value 13s. 1d.; the goods of the
South Western Railway company, his masters;to which he pleaded

GUILTY Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1435.
ELIZA THOMPSON and
JOSEPH ROBIN ON
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ELIZA COX. On 22nd April, about seven in the evening, Thompson came to my mistress's shop for a halfpenny-worth of thread—I served her—she gave me a fourpenny-piece—I put it into the till, and gave her 3 1/2d. change—she went away—there were half-crowns and shillings in the till, but no small money—I am sure there was no fourpenny-piece—after she was gone Troson came in—I went to the till and gave him the fourpenny-piece I re-ceived from Thompson—I identify it by a mark on it—no one bad been is the shop from the time Thompson came till Troson came

JOHN LOCK . On 22nd April, between six and seven in the evening, Thompson came to my shop for a pennyworth of tea—my wife served her—a man in private clothes at the door beckoned to me—Thompson gave my wife a fourpenny-piece—she laid it on the counter—I went round and took it up—it was bad—I said so—I bit it—Thompson said she did not know it, or something to that effect—soon afterwards the officer brought Robinson in.
MRS. LOCK. I served Thompson—what my husband has stated is true.

THOMAS TROSON (policeman, M 337.) On 22nd April, between six and seven in the evening, I was on duty in plain clothes, in Union-street, South-wark—I saw the prisoners in company and followed them—Thompson went into Cox's shop—Robinson stood in the street, in sight of the shop—Thompson came out and gave something to Robinson, and they went on

together—I went in and received this fourpenny-piece—I them followed them to Mr. Lock's—I took Robinson—he threw this fourpenny-piece from his left hand, and said he had not been pitching—I took him into Mr. Lock's shop, and found on him 5s. 2 1/2d. in coppers, 2s. in silver, and twenty-five packets of mustard, tea, pepper, and other things.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M 249.) I was with Troson on 22nd April, and saw the prisoners in Union-street—Robinson passed something to Thomp-son, about four yards from Cox's shop—Thompson entered the shop—Ro
binson passed the door—Thompson came out, joined Robinson, and gave him something, which he put into his coat-tail pocket—they then walked on to the New-cut—Thompson went into Mr. Lock's—Robinson waited outside, about fifteen yards off—I got this fourpenny-piece from Mr. Lock's.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these three fourpenny-pieces are counterfeit—two of them are cast in the same mould.

THOMPSON—
GUILTY. Aged 20.

ROBINSON—
GUILTY. Aged 18.

1436.
ANN PUMPHERY and
ANN MILLER
, for a like offence.
MESSRS. ROBINSON and SCRIVEN conducted the Prosecution.

MARY ANN POWELL. I am apprentice to Mr. Kingsman, a linen-draper of Westminster-bridge-road. On 5th May, the prisoners came to the shop—Pumphery asked for a pennyworth of black tape—I served her—she gave me a sixpence—I gave it to the cashier—he took it away—I saw no more of it.

THOMAS GROOBY. I am cashier at Mr. Kingsman's. I took the six
pence from Miss Powell—I gave it to Mr. Kingsman—a policeman was sent for—he took two other sixpences from pumphery's hand—she tried to swallow them.

WILLIAM KINGSMAN. My cashier brought me a bad sixpence, on 5th May—I took it, and walked down to the end of the shop, where the prisoners stood side by side—Miss Powell said pumphery gave it her—I asked Pum
phery where she got it, and whether she had any more—she said, "No." and she did not know it was bad—Miller said, "If I had known you wasted a penny I could have lent it you"—a policeman was sent for—he said to Pumphery, "What have you got in your hand"—she was trying to get it to her mouth—he seized her hand—she used very abusive language, and struggled very much—Miller was about to pull the policeman away—another policeman came in, and got two sixpences from Pumphery's hand—I marked the sixpence I had, and gave it to the officer.
DENNIS MURPHY (policeman, P 102). I produce two sixpences which I took from Pumphery's hand, and one which I got from Mr. Kingsman.
MARY HEARN. I searched the prisoners at the station—Pumphery asked to go to the water-closet—I saw something like money in her hand—she threw it down—I pointed it out to the officer.
----(policeman, L 48). I found this sixpences in the water-closet.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. These four sixpences are counterfeit—two of them have been cast in one mould.

PUMPHREY—
GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

MILLER—
NOT GUILTY.

1437.
ANN CURTIN and
ELIZABETH SMITH
, for a like offence.

JANE WALTON. I am servant to Mr. Robinson, of the Red Lion. On 14th April the prisoners came for half-a-quartern of gin—Curtin offered me a bad sixpence—I bent it—the prisoners were taken to the station, but were allowed to go away—I gave the sixpence to Wright.

ELIZABETH HUNT. I am barmaid to Mr. Brown. On 14th April the prisoners came—Curtin asked for some gin—she paid a fourpenny-piece—I took it up—it was bad—I bent it and gave it her back—Wright came in and took it from her hand.
JOHN WRIGHT (policeman, M 63). I produce two sixpences—I got one from Jane Walton, and the other and two fourpenny-pieces I took from Curtin's hand.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. These sixpences are counterfeit—these two fourpenny-pieces are coutnerfeit, and from the same mould.

Smith's Defence. I met this woman, who asked me to have something to drink—I said I had no money—the policeman laid hold of her hand and threw her on the ground—I said, "Don't hurt her," and they laid hold of me.

CURTIN—
GUILTY. Aged 31.—
Confined Nine Months.

SMITH—
NOT GUILTY.

1438.
JOHN ARTHUR RAWSON
, stealing 3 shirts and 2 shirt-collars, value 15s.; the goods of
Frederick Smith; to which he pleaded
GUILTY .—(see page 45.)

1439.
JAMES M'LOCHLIN
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles knight, at
Rotherhithe , and stealing 1 pump box, 1 flanch, and 1 swivel, value 2l. 3s., his goods.

CHARLES KNIGHT. I am a plumber, at Rotherhithe-street. On 26th Feb., about one o'clock, I left my shop—I returned in ten minutes and found the window broken and a brass box, a patent box, and a swivel gone—they were mine—it is my dwelling-house, in Rotherhithe parish.

THOMAS GREENSHIELD. On 26th Feb. I saw the prisoner with some brass under his apron—he gave the box of a pump to another person, who has been convicted, about three yards from the shop—I said I would go and tell—Carter afterwards sent me into a public-house—I saw the prisoner—he asked what I wanted—I went to tell Carter, and he got out at the back door.
RICHARD DRYDEN. On 26th Feb. I found this article lying at the King and Queen, under a boom—I kept it, and found the owner.

THOMAS GREENSHIELD
re-examined. This is like what I saw.
JOHN CARTHY (policeman). I went to take the prisoner at a public-house in Rotherhithe—I sent Greenshield in to see if he ws there—he came out, and the prisoner escaped the back way.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1440.
OWEN SHEEN , was indicted
for embezzlement.

THOMAS BOORAH. I am a dealer. An order for goods had been given to the prisoner in the name of Mansfield—he brought them on Friday, 24th March, and I paid him 2l.—he gave me this receipt—it is signed "Mansfield"—he represented himself as Mansfield—on 27th March I paid him 3l. 11s. 4d.—he represented himself as Mansfield, a nd signed the receipt Mansfield.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. You gave him the order for himself? A. He brought the card—I gave him the order.

THOMAS MANSFIELD. I employed the prisoner—I gave him the goods to go to Mr. Boorah—I authorised him to receive the money—he never paid me—I authorised him to receive money once before—on the Friday he received 2l., and never accounted for it—on the Saturday he came, and had 13s. 6d. for his wages—I found him in a public-house tipsy—he swore he never received it.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not know he had received this 2l.? A. No—he was paid according to what he did—I gave him half-a-crown for the job—I did not go to either of the customers before the money was received—I gave him the goods to carry out with another man—the money was to be paid to him—I went with him to the house—I remained ouside—he came out, and said Mr. Boorah was not in the way—I did not go in; they did not know me, and would not pay me—the prisoner had not known them before—he told me to stay outside—he received the order, and was to execute it—he had not been at work on the other transaction above a fortnight—I am sure the goods were mine.

GUILTY. Aged 49.—
Confined Two Months.

1441.
JAMES DOWDING and
JAMES HILLESLEY
, stealing 18lbs. weight of copper, value 8s.; the goods of
William John Loat, their master.

WILLIAM JOHN LOAT. I am a builder, at Clapham—Hillesley was my wagoner four or five months, and Dowding my gardener and odd-man. On 30th March I directed Hillesley to take the cart to Nine Elms; and on 6th April, in consequence of something I heard, I went to a stable on my pre
mises, and found a piece of copper, worth 7s. or 8s.—I had not missed it; it had been in a closet or cupboard, in a shed, which was always locked—the padlock appeared locked and perfect—it was fastened by a secrew-staple, but a person could take it out and put it much in the same state that it was in before.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you the copper here? A. This is it (produced)—I did not know how much there was in the place—probably I never should have missed any, but this had been the cover of a roof—this is a very common form for old copper to be in—Dowding has been in my service seven or eight years—I had a very hight opinion of him.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did Hillesley drive the cart? A. Yes—he lived with his family, at Balham-hill—he has been bailed, and has surrendered to take his trial.

JAMES MATTHEWS. I am a marine-store dealer, of Wandaworth. On 30th March, Hillesley came to my house a little after nine o'clock, and offered me this piece of copper for sale—I asked where he got it—he said it was no matter; there it was, if I chose to buy it—I said it would not suit me, he had better take it away again—he took it away—I informed the police.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. No—I am positive he is the man—I swear to the copper by some red paint on it.

ALFRED SPICE (policeman, V 41.) I received information from Mr. Matthews, and on 6th April went to a stable on Mr. Loat's premises with him and the sergeant, and this copper was found there—I afterwards took

Hillesley—I asked whether he knew anything about the copper—he said he knew nothing about anything—I afterwards showed him the copper—Mr. Loat told him he had better tell the truth—something was said, but I did not hear what.

ROBERT EMERSON (police-sergeant, 9 V.) I found this copper on 6th of April—I spoke to Hillesley about it—Mr. Loat told him he had better tell the truth—I waited till Dowding came—Mr. Loat said to him, "I have been informed some copper has been taken from my premises, and you know something about it"—Dowding said, "By whom have you been informed"—Mr. Loat said, "By Hillesley"—Dowding said, "Bring him before me" Mr. Loat said, "He is safe in custody"—Dowding stood a minute or five, and then said, "If I tell the truth, will you forgive me?"—Mr. Loat said, "I have nothing to do with it"—Dowding stood a second or so and said, "I had better tell you the truth; I will show you how I got it"—he went to the shed door, unscrewed the staple and the lock came off; you could then open the door.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Were you in uniform? A. Yes; I had seen Dowding before, but had no conversation with him—I heard nothing said to him before about unscrewing the lock—I had no suspicion that that was the way it had been done—nothing had been said to Dowding about the staple till he went to it.
(The prisoners received good characters, and a witness engaged to take Hillesley into his service.)

HILLESLEY—
GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy—
Confined One Month.

DOWDING—
GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy—
Confined Three Months.

1442.
JOHN MAHONEY and
JAMES BAILEY
, stealing 1 handker
chief, value 2s.; the goods of
William Painter, from his person.

MAHONEY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined One Month.

BAILEY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Nine Months.

1443.
ANTHONY DONALDSON
, stealing 1 half-sovereign; the moneys of
James Robison Cockburn, his master.

JAMES ROBISON COCKBURN. I am a pawnbroker, at Richmond—the pri
soner was my shopman for two years—it was his duty to take in pledges, deliver them, and do the general business—when he took in this watch he had to examine it, and to lend according to his judgment, to make out two duplicates; one for the person pledging, and the other he puts on the article—before giving the money, he enters it in the auction book—he gives the money without coming to me—he had marked 1l. on the ticket; he would ad
vance 19s. 10d., as we are entitled to 2d. on the ticket—he would enter in the auction book the name of the person, whether a housekeeper or a lodger, and the amount lent, 1l., to correspond with the duplicate—on Saturday, 8th April, I found this ticket for 1l. in the till, the time of pawning being on 3rd May, and on 8th April redeemed—I said to the prisoner, "You have charged more interest than you ought; you have charged 4s. on the back"—he said, "It is all right"—I said, "I suppose it is; you have only lent 1l. on it"—twelvemonth's interest would he 4s.—the interest on 1l. 10s. would be

5s. 8d.—by my finding the ticket in the till, it would have come in that day—he had been serving that day in the shop and he must have taken it—I afterwards examined the auction book—the amount entered there was 1l. 10s., as if he had lent 1l. 10s. on it—the date in the book was 3rd May, 1847, and from the entries I saw below it, and before it, it must have been entered on that date—on the Monday evening I went to my cash book, and I found for that day's entry but a very few halfpence in excess, and had he entered 1l. 10s., and charged on the ticket only 1l., there would have been an excess of 10s.—I have, certainly, never received that 10s.—I must have known if this 10s. had been in excess—he lent 1l. in May, 1847, which was paid to me in April, 1848, and in May, 1847, he credits his account in the book with 1l. 10s., whereas he only paid 1l.

FRANCIS BREWER. I am a tailor, and live opposite Mr. COckburn, at Richmond. On Tuesday, 11th April, the prisoner came over to my shop—he asked me if I would allow him to burn some old letters and old books—I told him to go in the back kitchen, and he was in the act of tearing out some leaves and throwing them in the fire—he said his master suspected he had been robbing him, but he should not see the books—he said he should be imprisoned for what he had been doing, but he did not care for that—he said he should go out the back way—I said no, he came in the front way and he should go out that way—I then told the prosecutor.

1444.
ANTHONY DONALDSON
was again indicted
, for embesslement.

FREDERICK GAYDON. I am assistant to Mr. Loden, a watch and clock maker, in Blackfriars-road. A little before Christmas, 1846, I pawned two pairs of trowsers at different times, at Mr. Cockburn's; one pair for 12s. or 14s., and the other for 8s.—about Christmas, 1847, I sent 23s. to redeem them, by a post-office order, payable to the prisoner—my trowers were sent by the Parcel's Delivery Company in three or four days afterwards—some time afterwards I met the prisoner in London; I asked him what money there was deficient—he said 9d. or 1s. 9d., and I paid it him—he had written to me about the post office order, and said it was 9d. or 1s. 9d. deficient, and when I met him I paid it—he said he received the order; it was all right—I sent the duplicates with the order—I made the order payable to the prisoner because I had been in Mr. Cockburn's service, and did not wish him to know I pawned the things with the prisoner.

JAMES ROBISON COCKBURN. The prisoner was in my service—the book in which this money should have been entered as paid in 1846 is destroyed—I have examined my books—it is not entered as received at Christmas, 1847—I have not received the Post-office order—if these trowsers were desired by the witness to he sent home by the Parcels Delivery Company, it would have been the prisoner's duty to have entered them in this parcel-delivery book—here are my entries, Mrs. Cockburn's, and the prisoner's, in it—here is no entry of this parcel being sent—it would be the prisoner's duty to enter the parcel, for my protection—if it had been lost I should have been exonerated, because I sent it by the party that they had mentioned—I am sure the pri
soner never accounted to me for this.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Will you undertake to say that the money was never paid you? A. To the best of my belief, it never was—I will swear it was never accounted for to me—no parcel was ever

allowed to be sent out without being entered in this parcel-delivery book—here are two entries of 12s. and 9s.—without having the books, which are destroyed, it is impossible for me to tell what goods they refer to—the trowsers were pawned for 14s. and 8s.—on 11th Dec., here is entered 2s. 1d. interest, and 12s. principal—I should say this is not the entry of the trowsers, because the witness says they were 14s. and 8s.—I know nothing about the taking them out.

STEPHEN CREED (policeman, V 200.) I took the prisoner—I found this letter in his box—it is signed, "Frederick Gaydon"—(read)—"To Mr. Donaldson, at Mr. Cockburn's, Richmond, Surrey. 16, Blackfriars-road, Oct. 14, 1847. Dear Donaldson, I herewith inclose you a Post-office order for 23s. If you will be kind enough to make those two pairs of trowsers in a paper-parcel, and send it by the London Parcel Delivery Company as soon as possible, you will oblige. If it comes to more than I have sent, please let me know."

1445.
ANTHONY DONALDSON was again indicted
for stealing 1 cigars
case, value 10s., the goods of
James Robison Cockburn, his master.

STEPHEN CREED (policeman V 200.) I produce this cigar-case—I found it in the prisoner's box, on 19th April, in his room, at the top of Mr. Cock
burn's house.

JAMES ROBISON COCKBURN. This cigar-case was part of my stock—I am not quite clear when I saw it last—I think a month or six weeks before it was found it was put into the trade stock for the prisoner to sell—it was not sold, or we should have it entered in this sale-book—(produced)—the selling price is half-a-guinea—it was never reported to me as having been sold.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Will you undertake to swear you saw it within the last six months? A. I cannot say—my stock is large—there may be things that I have not seen for two or three years—I am con
fident this has not been sold since I gave it the prisoner to sell—I have a jeweller's shop—I sometimes bring things from there to the sale-shop—if the sale-shop pays for them there would be no entry of them—this book contains the amount of things entered—I suppose we do not sell 1l. worth in three months without entering them—it might be that no entry was made of this article—the prisoner never paid me any money for it—he said two or three people had looked at it, and asked the price—part of it is silver—I do not know that I told him so—he has had no conversation with me about purchasing it—I never said it was valued at 4s.—I have lost upwards of 300l.

GUILTY.—
Confined Six Months.

1446.
JOHN BATEMAN
, stealing 1 gun, value 10l., the goods of
William Bereford.

WILLIAM PERKINS. I am a gamekeeper to Mr. Gooding, of Breestock Lodge, Northamptonshire. I have had letters in the prisoner's name which I have reason to believe were not written by him—in Sept. last, I received a gun and a letter in the same writing as that I used to receive from the prisoner—in about a week I received a letter signed J. Bateman, telling me to take care of the gun that was sent down—I sent back a letter to know how he came by it—he wrote saying he had it from John Mays—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. How long have you had it? A.

About eight months. I am a relation of the prisoner's—I have destroyed the letter—he said he had it from John Mays for a debt due from him for board and lodging—he did not say it was to be kept till Mays paid him—it looked like a woman's writing—the prisoner cannot write, unless he has learned since he has been in London.

WILLIAM BERESFORD. I live in the Temple. In June last I had a gun which was removed with other things, from my residence at Islington, to my brother's warehouse in Tooley-street—it was missed about Sept.—this is it.

JOSEPH SUTTON. In June las I was removing Mr. Beresford's goods with the prisoner and four others—I moved what I believe was a gun in a wollen case—I saw it in the warehouse in Tooley-street—I saw it put away—the prisoner was there.

DANIEL BROWN. I am in the service of Marcus Bereford, of Pickle-her
ring wharf—the goods were removed there in June—a gun was brought from the van to me—I saw it in the warehouse—the prisoner was employed there up to the time he was charged, and had access to it—it was missed about three months afterwards—Mr. Beresford asked me, I said I knew nothing of it—he called the prisoner and asked him, he said he knew nothing of it.

Cross-examined. Q. He had been employed a long time at the wharf? A. Yes; Mays had been employed there, but was not then—I don't think I have seen him these six months—I have heard that he is dead, that he was starved and could not get employ.
THOMAS WEST (policeman.) I took the prisoner, he said he knew nothing of the gun—I went to Northamptoushire and found it.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor—

div1.p:
1447.
WILLIAM PORTSMOUTH
, stealing 16lbs., weight of solder, value 10s. and 49lbs. weight of lead, 6s.; the goods of
Edward Hoile and another, his masters.

JOSEPH WONFER. I live at No. 5, Caledonian-cottages, Battersea. I have one partner, named Edward Hoile—the prisoner was in my service—we were making alterations—we had a quantity of lead on our premises and factory.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you miss any? A. No—it was impossible—the prisoner was brought back and searched in my presence—this lead was found inside his trowsers—he said, "Pray forgive me"—he has been several years in service in that house—he was there when we took the premise—I believe this to be our property.

ALFRED HARDEMAN (policeman, V 73.) I took the prisoner. I found this piece of solder in his side pocket, and these forty-nine pounds of lead buttoned in the flap of his trowsers—this cord went round his neck to hold it up.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY.—
Confined Three Months.

1448.
JOHN FINCH and
JAMES GOSBELL
, stealing 4 sacks, and 2 quarters of malt, value 6l. 4s., the goods of
William Jupp and others, the masters of Gosbell, he having been before convicted.
MATTHEW HENRY COWELL. I am in partnership with William Jupp and Mr. Wilks. We are brewers at St. George's-road, Southwark—Gosbell was in

our employ—on Friday 12th May we were to receive twenty-five quarters of malt in fifty sacks, from Mr. Jupp—Finch came with it—he was in Mr. Jupp's service, the malster—he brought this receipt and delivery not after, as I supposed the malt was delivered—Finch and Gosbell came into the counting-house—I asked Finch whether he had delivered twenty-five quarter—he said, "Yes"—I asked Gosbell whether he had received twenty-five quar
ters—he said, "Yes"—I then signed the receipt note and gave it to Finch—I afterwards received a communication from Newton, went into the granary and counted the sacks; there were but forty-six—I then followed the prisoners and found them in a public house—I asked Finch what he had got in his wagon, he said, two quarters of malt—he said, he hoped he had not done wrong and should not get himself into a scrape, but our man Gosbell ordered him to take them somewhere else—I told him to draw round—Gosbell went into the biewery—I sent for an officer and took him—he came—I asked him how it was—he said he thought the whole twenty-five quarters were delivered.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When Finch said he had deli
vered the twenty-five quarters, if was the quantity he had delivered to Gosbell. A. Yes; Gosbell was the party to receive malt—Finch might have supposed that Gosbell had authority to dispose of the two quarters—I have heard an excellent character of Finch.

THOMAS NEWTON. I am in the employ of Jupp and Co. On Friday, 12th May, I saw twenty-three quarters delivered—Finch was in the wagon—he had got the next sack ready, the mount of it in his hand, waiting for the chain of the crane to come down; but instead of the chain, Gosbell came down—I asked why he did not pull the other two quarters up—he said, "That is going to the railway"—he went out to Finch—I told my master directly. THOMAS BAILEY. I am foreman to William Jupp, a maltster. On 12th May I gave Finch twenty-five quarters of malt to deliver to Mr. Cahell—if was his duty to deliver fifty sacks—when he left the wharf I saw no more of him.

Cross-examined. Q. How long has Finch been in your service? A. Seven years—he has delivered thousands of quarters—I never knew any
thing against him—his master will take him back directly.
ALFRED WAKEFIELD (policeman, L 117.) I took Gosbell—he said he thought he had delivered it all.

(MR. METCALFE, on behalf of Gosbell, submitted that the property was never in the prosecutor's possession; MR. PARRY contended that the receipt by the servant was that of the master, and the COURT so held.)
GEORGE TAYLOR (police-sergeant, L 29.) I produce a certificate of Gosbell's former conviction—(read—Convicted May, 1845, and confined six weeks)—he is the man.

FINCH—
NOT GUILTY.

GOSBELL—
GUILTY. Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years.

1449.
JESSE JAMES BURDETT,
GEORGE WALLER , and
ELI
ZABETH ELLIS
, stealing 41 numbers of the London Journal, value 3s. 5d.; the goods of
Henry Barrington Francis and others; Waller having been before convicted.

HENRY BARRINGTON FRANCIS. I am in partnership with my two sons. Last Saturday evening, at half-past nine o'clock, I came home and went into my shop—the prisoners were brought in—I missed forty-one numbers of the London Journal—they were brought in with the prisoners, and were our property.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M 249.) About nine o'clock last Saturday I saw the prisoners in company in Old Kent-road—I followed them to Mr. Francis's in Alfred-place—Waller passed and repassed the window—I went on, came back, and saw Burdett leave the shop-door, and place these numbers in Waller's apron—I stopped them—Ellis said, "They are ours"—Waller threw them from his apron, and Ellis ran off with them—I pursued and took her—Burdett was brought back—he said he would pay for them.
Burdett's Defence. I went in, and asked the young man if he had got any old numbers; he said, "Yes," I could have them for a shilling.
WILLIAM JENNINGS (policeman, M 273.) I produce a certificate of Waller's former conviction—(read—Convicted Dec., 1846, and confined two Months)—he is the man.

*BURDETT—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

**WALLER—
GUILTY. Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

ELLIS—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined One Month.

1450.
THOMAS CRAWLEY,
JOHN WILLSHER , and
WILLIAM RUTT
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
William Johns, from his person.

WILLIAM JOHNS. I live at Kennington. On 28th April, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Walworth-road—I felt my handkerchief taken out of my pocket—I turned, and the prisoners were behind me—I charged Rutt with having taken it—while I was speaking, West came and took him.
Rutt. Q. Did I go away? A. No.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M 249.) I was in Westminster-road between seven and eight o'clock that evening—I saw the prisoner Crawley try a lady's pocket, Willsher was covering him—they went on and attempted another pocket, but did not succeed—they went on to the Walworth-road—Crawley put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and took out something white—I asked if he had lost anything—he said, "A white handkerchief," but he should not know it—in about ten minutes Mr. Johns passed—the pri
soners followed him about 200 yards—Willsher stepped into the road, just by a stall—this handkerchief, which Mr. Johns claims, was found there—I went up, and found Rutt in conversation with Johns, who said, "They; have just picked my pocket"—I took Rutt and Willsher—Rutt said, "I know nothing of that man," meaning Willsher.
THOMAS TOURESEY (policeman, M 237.) I was watching the prisoners—I saw what West has stated—they were all trying pockets.
MARTHA EASTER. I wa sitting at my stall about half-past eight o'clock that evening—I saw a handkerchief lying—I picked it up and gave it to West.

†CRAWLEY—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

†*WILLSHER—
GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

†RUTT—
GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE 12TH, 1848.
